title.narrative: Supporting A Green/Blue Economy: Liberia Blue Ocean Program
Supporting A Green/Blue Economy: Liberia Blue Ocean Program

description.narrative:
Conservation International (CI) har sökt svensk finansiering om 20 miljoner svenska kronor för att genomföra det 4-åriga programmet "The Blue Oceans Program". Programmet som CI initialt presenterade bedömdes av ambassaden som svagt gällande programdesign, ägandeskap och hållbarhet. För att åtgärda bristerna kommer CI genomföra en inledningsfas mellan december 2019 till december 2020 med en budget på 4 800 000 svenska kronor. Inledningsfasen möjliggör för förbättring av programdesignen samt för vidare bedömning av projektets omfattning. Inledningsfasen gör också möjligt för ambassaden att bedöma om ägarskap samt hållbarhet ur ett långsiktigt perspektiv.
The Blue Oceans Program bygger handlingsplanen från The Blue Oceans Conference (BOC) som hölls i mars 2019 och erhöll svenskt stöd.
Insatsen syftar till att bibehålla intresset som väcktes vid The Blue Oceans Conference, samt upprätthålla och följa upp handlingsplanen som resultat av konferensen. Insatsen har fyra tematiska komponenter – blå ekonomi, havsföroreningar, hållbart fiske, och klimatförändringar.
Målet med the Blue Oceans Program är att främja ett hållbart förhållningsätt till Liberias kust och marina ekosystem genom rehabilitering och bevarande av havs- och kustekosystem för att lindra fattigdom, skydda den biologiska mångfalden samt mildra och anpassa sig till klimatförändringarna.
Insatsen har fyra mål: (1) Evidensbaserad förståelse för vad som påverkar kust- och havsekosystemens hälsa; (2) Förbättra cirkulära ekonomiska strategier för att hantera havsföroreningar; (3) Främja effektiv reglering och integrerad förvaltning av kust- och havsekosystem; och (4) Förbättra befolkningens kunskap och medvetenhet om kust- och de marina ekosystemens hälsa och bevarande.
Målet med den inledande fasen är att specificera det geografiska området, från Liberias kuststräcka som helhet, (Cape Mount till Cape Palmas) till mer koncentrerade områden, utföra kontextuell analys av Liberias kust och marina miljö, uppdatera programdesignen, förändringsteorin och resultatramverket, samt sträva efter nationellt ägarskap för projektet. Det kommer genomföras en konflikt och jämställdhetsanalys av kvinnors roll inom blå ekonomi; inklusive fiske, analys av aktörer, en studie i hantering av plastavfall; en bedömning av den nuvarande fattigdomssituationen; blå ekonomi; hållbart fiske; marin nedskräpning och klimatförändringar; snabb marin bedömning samt utbildning av ambassadens samarbetspartners i miljö och klimat.
CI är en internationell icke-statlig organisation etablerad år 1987 med huvudkontor i USA. De har arbetat med bevarandet av miljö och natur i över trettio år. CI har funnits i Liberia sedan 1999 och 2002 öppnade de kontor i landet. CI har samarbetat med relevanta nationella aktörer inom miljö och den marina sektorn i Liberia under nästan tjugo år. CI är en av Sidas samarbetspartners och vilka genomförde 2019 års Blue Oceans Conference.

Conservation International (CI) has applied to the Embassy of Sweden support of 20 million SEK to carry out a 4-year intervention, the “Blue Ocean Program”. The program was assessed by the Embassy as weak in terms of scope, design, ownership and sustainability. To address these weaknesses CI will be conducting an inception phase, December 2019 to December 2020 with a budget of 4 800 000 SEK. The inception phase is motivated to allow for improvement in the project design and for CI to have the possibility to better assess the scope of the project. The inception phase also gives the Embassy the possibility to assess ownership and sustainability of the program in terms of long-term support beyond the inception phase.
The intervention builds on the mandate from Blue Ocean Conference (BoC), which was held in March 2019 and was supported by the Embassy of Sweden.
The purpose of the intervention is to maintain the moment generated during the BOC and sustain its outcomes. The goal of the Blue Oceans Program is to promote sustainable management of Liberia’s coastal and marine ecosystems through conservation and restoration of marine and coastal ecosystem services to alleviate poverty, protect biodiversity, and mitigate and adapt to climate change.
The intervention has four objectives: (1) Enhancing science-based understanding of drivers impacting coastal and marine ecosystem health and services; (2) Enhancing circular economy approaches addressing marine pollution; (3) To promote effective governance and integrated management of coastal and marine ecosystems; and (4) Enhancing education and outreach /public awareness on the topic of coastal and marine ecosystem health and preservation.
The program has four main components – blue economy, marine pollution, sustainable fishery, and climate change. The Embassy’s priority areas regarding the four thematic areas will be clarified after the inception phase.
During the inception phase, the geographical scope of the program will be specified and narrowed down from the entire coastal line, (Cape Mount to Cape Palmas) to concentrated areas. Furthermore, CI will focus on conducting coastal and marine contextual analysis to inform the” Blue Ocean Program” programming, as well as refine the program design, the Theory of Change and the Results Framework and seek to achieve ownership among national stakeholders. Key activities that will be implemented during the inception phase are: conflict and gender sensitivity analysis on the role of women in the blue economy, including fishery; stakeholder analysis; a study on plastic waste pollution; assessment of current state of poverty, blue economy, sustainable fisheries, marine pollution, and climate change; marine rapid assessment; and training of Embassy of Sweden partners in mainstreaming environment and climate change.
Established in 1987, CI is a US based international nongovernmental organization that has been working in global conservation for over three decades. In Liberia, CI has been active since 1999, and established an office in 2002. CI has nearly two decades of experience engaging stakeholders in the marine and environment domain at all levels in Liberia. CI is a Sida partner, having implemented the 2019 Liberia Blue Ocean Conference.

Conservation International main goal of supporting A Green/Blue Economy: Liberia Ocean Program is to promote sustainable management of Liberia’s coastal and marine ecosystems by achieving the following objectives and outcomes: Objective 1: Enhanced science-based understanding of drivers impacting coastal and marine ecosystem health and service. Outcome 1 Coastal and marine science-based baseline data and information generated to inform blue ocean programming and decision making. Objective 2. Enhanced circular economy approaches addressing marine pollution Outcome 2 Reduced influx of plastics to coastal and marine waters. Objective 3: Effective governance and integrated management of coastal and marine ecosystems Outcome 3.1 Strategic plan for establishment of National and/or Transboundary Integrated Coastal and MPA(s) developed. Outcome 3.2 Multi-stakeholder Blue Oceans Strategy and Action Plan developed. Outcome 3.3 Effective implementation, coordination, and management of the BOP. Outcome 3.4 Increased community stewardship in coastal and marine conservation. Outcome 3.5 Effective knowledge management for the BOP. Outcome 3.6 Improved capacity on coastal and marine conservation. Objective 4. Enhanced education and outreach /public awareness Outcome 4. Increased community knowledge and participation in coastal and marine stewardship activities.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sida and Conservation International Foundation

description.narrative:
Introduction Conservation International is a US based organization working in more than 40 countries and over 20 years in west Africa on conservation and environmental. In Liberia, CI aims to demonstrate that sustainable development is achievable in Liberia through an integrated landscape approach that seeks to balance nature conservation, production, and economic development. CI-Liberia has supported the Government of Liberia in the creation of protected areas, and the incorporation of surrounding communities in the management of those areas including policies such as the Agenda for Transformation, the Low Carbon Development Strategy and the introduction of Conservation Agreement model, which makes biodiversity conservation a viable choice for local resource users through voluntary agreements that provide tangible benefits in exchange for verified conservation actions. As an outcome of the 2019 Blue Oceans Conference (BOC) held in Monrovia, Liberia, a Call to Action statement with voluntary commitments was developed. These commitments incorporate existing frameworks at the international, regional and national levels for sustainable development, specifically those strategies related to conservation and management of the ocean and marine resources. An agreement was signed between The Embassy and CI for the support to a three-year intervention consisting of a 1-year inception phase to promote sustainable management of Liberia’s coastal and marine ecosystem. The inception phase seeks to address some of the weaknesses in identified areas of the proposal. The objective of the inception phase is to seek stakeholder buy-in, conduct coastal and marine context analysis, develop environmental and social safeguards to properly inform the design of the program for the coming years. To this end, the conclusion of the inception phase, CI will have achieved these area be the implementation to commence. Two results achieved BOP baseline established. Baseline information was collected including on target sites, beneficiaries, and completed planned consultancies on: a.) Gender and conflict analysis - This has contributed to multiple forms of community level conflict. Conflict over limited water resources and open defecation in the majority of coastal communities, Land disputes between community members and the government, as a result of the same plot of land being sold to multiple buyers, is prevalent in the Southeastern coastal counties were some of the results. b.) Marine plastics pollution study The study identified drivers of marine plastics in Liberia include: Mismanagement of municipal solid waste (MSW), which is one of the key drivers of the entry of plastic waste into the marine environment in Liberia. In Monrovia, solid waste collection coverage is 45% (The World Bank Report, 2019), making open dumping of waste prevalent. Inadequate capacity of skips for secondary collection of waste leads to leakage of waste into waterways, near wetlands and swamps, and on beaches. In Buchanan, solid waste collection in the entire town is done by one waste management truck. Solid waste collection services do not cover communities along the coast due to inaccessibility, and waste is openly dumped and buried in swamps and along beaches. In Greenville, Marshall, and Robertsport residents are responsible for the management of their own solid waste. Burying and burning in swamps and along the beaches is a common practice. c.) Marine dependent industries under the auspices of blue economy - summary of key results Stakeholders are mostly moderately aware of blue economy aspects, with many in the private sector/communities having minimal awareness. They do however have a high awareness of fisheries and tourism opportunities. Issues of concern by the cross section of stakeholders include marine pollution and climate change, 54% and 43% respectively. Other issues of concern are illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing (37%); coastal erosion (34%), and illegal sand mining (27%). d.) Rapid assessment in Liberia of coastal and marine resources Information gathered during the rapid assessment on the marine and coastal habitat of Liberia is sufficient to inform the establishment of Marine Protected Areas and the development of community-based sustainable fisheries, as the information gathered is detailed and informative enough for stakeholders to make decisions. However, information on corals and seagrass is generic because there is a huge information gap and will require further detailed exploration to ascertain the location, biodiversity, and species distribution. Information was generated and updated for the following key ecosystems. Other deliverables achieved are studies on Marine Reptiles, coastal birds, protected areas and fishes 2. Deliverable 4 and 5: Clarified scope and identified project site Another deliverable achieved by the BOP is the identification of project site and beneficiary coastal local communities that are mostly affected by plastic pollution and other environmental issues. A map has been developed indicating the cities/communities from Grand Cape Mount along the coastline to Maryland county. BOP also has considered the protected areas along the coastline in its program.
Deliverable xiii: Recruit and hire Blue Oceans Programme Director. The BOP programme director, Mike Olendo, was recruited (1st October 2020), hired and has been leading the BOP work during the inception phase.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
